ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also wrote discussion posts on our reading before each class that were generally engaging.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to write argumentative essays and the importance of signposting in writing. I also gained a lot of insights into the many different versions of truth, and how "truth" can be manipulated by those in power to satisfy their own end goals, how philosophers have thought about truth in relation to scientific advancements, and how truth is influenced by our subconscious bias and the information that we know about the world but others may not that cause these biases.
Reading comprehension, writing, critical thinking.
Analytical skills for literature, developing arguments, a new and more "free" way of writing
Close reading, signposting, and thinking critically about evidence and epistemology.

Knowledge of the history of the philosophy behind science and the idea of truth, and well as critical writing skills. In particular, we learned how to place two authors in conversation with each other in an essay.
I enhanced my writing skills and knowledge about truth and power within literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the feedback on essay drafts and ideas is really good; combined with the instructor sign-ups Prof Ranks hosts after each draft submission, you know exactly where to improve.

Weaknesses: the professor sometimes fishes for answers during class discussions. Discussion also lagged at times a lot in class, but I feel like that may be a result of moreso the student composition in the class and interest in the specific topic talked about in class than any reflection on the professor. The big thing for me though would probably be that it takes an extremely long time for the professor to grade our papers (for example, I submitted my final paper (i.e. the fourth paper of the course) before I even got my second paper's grade back).
I really enjoyed this class. It was challenging but doable, and I truly felt like a learned a lot.

Strengths: the discussion posts which helped guide the day's lecture/discussion points, breakout rooms, and seminar style format

Cons: getting paper back took a very long time... I only received my first paper back before the semester ended and we wrote 4 papers

I think it was good to start off with more dense texts and then gradually move to ones with more modern language and clear arguments.  It helped build the close reading and critical thinking skills early on so that later I felt like I could see deeper points within the more modern books/stories.  A weakness would just be getting feedback on essays.  It's always hard to know how to improve without feedback from previously written essays.  However, feedback on drafts was always very helpful while also being kind which is hard for a lot of people to do, so I appreciated that.

Some strengths are that Prof. Ranks was super engaging and clearly passionate about the subject, and the choice of readings. Class discussions were also generally quite fun, as well as the breakout rooms. It might be improved by having more timely grading for the four essays, as we only had one essay graded by the end of the term, and therefore did not have a good idea of our grades throughout the semester.
The reading materials were fantastic and prompted very solid discussions, yet the course may have been too focused specifically on truth and power. The writing, as a result, was somewhat limited.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion format over zoom was good --sometimes a little awkward though. The discussion posts were also helpful.

I think the zoom format worked surprisingly well, and discussions took some adaptation but became smooth and engaging. The reading posts were also a great way to engage outside of the classroom, and gather our thoughts for class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This course is great for improving your writing overall. Professor Ranks offers insightful feedback and is always willing to set up office hours if you need it.

I would recommend this class to all students! Even though I am a STEM major, this English class was incredible! I learned so much and really enjoyed all of the texts we read and the discussions we were able to have. I felt that I was able to connect with my classmates even though the course was completely online.

Yes! I would!! The course material was engaging and Professor Ranks is very nice and passionate about the course. If you don't mind getting papers back late, this course is a fun way to fulfill the writing requirement.
Yes if they need a writing class, enjoy literature, and especially if they enjoy science fiction.

Yes, especially if they are interested in the topic and the reading list. I particularly enjoyed the first unit on "building the body of truth", and if you enjoy science fiction and dystopian literature, you will likely enjoy the rest of the course too!
I would recommend this course if the effort in providing feedback was heavily improved because it offered a new, nuanced approach to viewing literature and the outside world.
